## Data background
## Where does the data come from? Who collected it? Why was it collected? Are you able to find the data from the original source?

This data comes from the NYPD website and is collected by the Office of Management Analysis and Planning of the New York City Police Department. This dataset provides a general overview of the nature of police enforcement activity in NYC by the NYPD to the public starting from 2006. The data can be found on the original website.
## Are there any issues you can see with how the data was collected? What is the sample population? Are there reasons to think the sample is biased in some way?\

The collection of NYPD Arrest Data raises several concerns regarding its collection and subsequent analysis. Issues such as selection bias may emerge, given the dataset exclusively represents individuals who have been arrested, potentially skewing the representation of certain crimes or demographic groups due to law enforcement priorities or practices. Additionally, reporting biases might result from inconsistencies in how incidents are documented across different precincts or by individual officers, affecting data uniformity and reliability. Human error in data entry could introduce inaccuracies, including misclassifications or incorrect demographic information, which could mislead analyses, particularly in trend or demographic studies.

This sample population consists of individuals arrested by the NYPD, as recorded in this dataset for the year to date. It represents only the subset of the population that has been arrested and does not reflect the broader New York City population.

There might be some biases in the sample. In the dataset, certain age groups are disproportionately represented. Most arrested individuals are in the age group of 25-44. This could reflect targeted law enforcement actions towards specific age demographics or broader societal issues affecting those age groups. Additionally, the dataset disproportionately represents certain demographics in terms of race. It may introduce bias in analyses that rely on this data, potentially reflecting or exacerbating existing societal or systemic biases.

## How is this data used? Has there been other research on the same data? Is this data being used for some policy decisions? What questions have others ask about this data?

This data can be used to inform policy decisions related to law enforcement practices, resource allocation, and community support programs. By analyzing patterns and trends in the data, policymakers can identify areas in need of intervention or reform. Moreover, researchers may examine the data to study crime trends, the effectiveness of policing strategies, and the impact of socio-economic factors on crime rates.
